body:
Status as of 2/12: AWS cloudformation stack created. cloud-init step not fully working yet. Jenkins server created, with admin account and security enabled.

Up next is to get cloud-init working before moving on.
cloud-init is working.
Working on enabling Jenkins security. Currently having a timing issue between jenkins install and execution of configuration script.

Security is now enabled during initial Puppet run (fixed wait condition in Jenkins bootstrap script).

Moving on to use of hieradata to support providing user account details.

How to enable hieradata:
https://docs.puppetlabs.com/hiera/3.0/configuring.html#changing-the-config-file-location

Also exploring use of KMS for encryption/decryption:
http://www.rubydoc.info/gems/hiera-eyaml-kms/0.1

The idea would be that the private key is owned by the 'baseball' project (or whatever project is using the standard-aws setup) and any hieradata is encrypted with this key and staged prior to calling standard-aws create.sh. The standard-aws template takes the KMS key as an argument.

CloudFormation already supports the creation of keys. A CF Stack in the baseball project can create the key and pass it along

This would be awesome...
This is done.

Update as of 2/26/2016:
Jenkins is getting installed, but Jenkins plugin installs are hanging. Need to move installation of all plugins to Jenkins bootstrap script which is being run by common Puppet module. Also need to be able to pass Jenkins seed project details via hieradata.

This is my attempt at some kind of mock-up:

![img_20160227_004722](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1299268/13371086/ce443fee-dceb-11e5-8a93-376c2f04ebfd.jpg)
Thanks Chris.
For cleaning up Steve's mess.
RC = runs created
RC = an example of a stat that someone might want to compute with this tool
Looks good, Steve. You the man!
Thanks Steve.

Moved this content to a wiki page, as a UI overview:
https://github.com/bryantrobbins/baseball/wiki/UI

Will split out more specific stories for UI features.

Update as of 2/28/2016:
A clean install of Jenkins and plugins generally works. I did see one odd hangup due to "yum is in use by another process". Am guessing that Puppet and something with cloud-init may have been conflicting here, so I will look into it.

Another issue is that Jenkins is not being added to the Docker group. This manual command does the trick (requires restart of Jenkins after being executed):

```
sudo gpasswd -a jenkins docker
```

This is more of a feature of the standard-aws project than baseball. Right now, standard-aws is hard-coded to use the baseball repo and its subdir for configuration of the seed project. It also uses a hard-coded password for the Jenkins admin.
Descoping this from the MVP. Will add in next round.

I'll take a swing at this

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6126140/13412572/2ab71dd2-df12-11e5-9846-11ae13ab42ea.png)
Terrible.
Since I've been working on this, you can slap it on me

ECR repo, ECS cluster, and ECS cluster instances now getting successfully created when initial CloudFormation is run.

I'm going to split the remaining work implied by this ticket into its own little issues.
LGTM

There is a puppet module for installing Consul:
https://github.com/solarkennedy/puppet-consul

These are added as cloud-init steps to the ECS Cluster Launch Configuration. Tested end-to-end.

May want to look at moving this into Puppet configuration down the road, as this would be at least a bit more cloud-agnostic (even though we are very tied to ECS at the moment).

This is also working, and built into the BuildHost for now (in the standard-aws template and puppet code, rather than the baseball project).

Have tested this with 1 and 2 containers.
This is done, as part of the standard-aws stack which brings up the build host.
This is working. A Jenkins job deploy-DEV takes args for UI container count and version.
This is working as part of the ui-image build.

The jenkins group membership is resolved. There is a "manage_user" flag on the jenkins puppet module, which allows me to manage my own user and its groups.

I have seen several clean installs of Jenkins work like a charm. Calling this DONE.
